text: Prioritizing work can be frustrating,

especially if you work for a hands-off manager 
or a company that doesn’t give you clear goals.

Research shows that more than 90% of 
employees don’t fully understand their

company’s strategy or know what’s expected 
of them to help achieve company goals ...

and on the other hand ... global executives say 
they have too many conflicting priorities.

In a world where conflicting and 
unclear priorities are the norm,

how can you learn to prioritize your own work 
and still feel satisfaction from a job well done?

Here is an organizing framework that 
can help determine your next steps:

First, take ownership ... by checking your 
mindset when it comes to setting priorities.

Don’t assume that prioritizing your workload 
is someone else’s job, and don’t choose to see

yourself solely as a “do-er” or a “workerbee.”
It’s easy to blame our managers and organizations

when we experience high levels of stress 
or an overwhelming amount of work. But,

it’s important to recognize that consciously 
setting priorities ourselves leads to success.

Then, filter your priorities by selecting a 
couple of areas to focus on; this can help

your brain manage information overload.
Research indicates that it’s the overload

of options that paralyze us or lead to 
decisions that go against our best interests.

You can filter your priorities based 
on two criteria: contribution and

passion. Ask yourself these questions:
What is your highest contribution?

When reflecting on contribution, consider both 
the organization’s needs and how your strengths,

experience, and capabilities play a unique 
role. Contribution captures a sense of purpose,

citizenship, and service.
What are you passionate about?

Motivation and energy fuel action, 
so when setting priorities,
get clarity on what inspires your work.

Third, determine your next steps 
with an organizing framework.

You can create an organizing framework by 
combining the two criteria of contribution

and passion to sort priorities 
and define subsequent actions.

Consider this chart:
Prioritize those areas of your

job that bring together your highest value-add 
and make an impact that inspires and excites you.

Tolerate those parts of the job that are 
important but drain your energy when you’re

engaging in them. Aim to tolerate and accept that 
you aren’t going to love every part of the job ...

and that you may be on a learning curve.
Elevate those tasks that give you energy

but that others don’t see as the best use of 
your time. Share what fuels your conviction,

and explain why it’s good for you and the company!
Delegate the daily churn of low-value and

low-energy-producing activities, emails, and 
meetings. If there’s no one to delegate to,

make the case for hiring someone. You can 
also just say no, or eliminate those tasks

altogether. The irony is, as we progress in our 
careers, things that were once in “Prioritize”,

now belong in “Delegate”. If people still come 
to you for these tasks, redirect them graciously.

And finally, operationalize and 
flag priorities in your calendar.

Look back on your calendar over 
the last month to see how much
time you allocated across the four quadrants.

Try using a color-coding system in your calendar 
to quickly and visually see how you’re doing.

At the start of a new week, flag all priorities 
to give yourself extra preparation time.

Don’t settle for the status quo – if you don’t 
prioritize your time, someone else will. And

it won’t always be with your best interests or 
the greater good in mind. So, take ownership

and reclaim decision-making power over where you 
can best spend your time and energy. By doing so,

you can produce meaningful results, experience 
more job satisfaction, and have increased energy.
